timeline.bodyText: For some reason I do not know the catch did not catch my 404 (because there was no working backend). Which lead into an ever rotating spinner button. It is a minor issue but I wanted to mention it.
timeline.author: kmerz

replies.bodyText: Maybe we can have a look together at this problem together? If it is reproducible. When I get a 404 it looks like this:
replies.author: linuspahl

timeline.bodyText: I do not know how it look right now, since I am not that advanced in testing, but I would recommend to do the error message in a mono font.
timeline.author: kmerz

replies.bodyText: I am not against using a mono font, but in all other error cases I found we are using the default font.
replies.author: linuspahl

replies.bodyText:
As it might be, here we are displaying raw data. It is not created in the frontend but in the backend. We might not even know how it looks, because it might be different depending on our authentication server we try to test again:
So I prefer:

over this:
replies.author: kmerz

timeline.bodyText: This is a bit awkward, that you define it here but never use it in this component. Perhaps move it to its own file. What do you think?
timeline.author: kmerz

timeline.bodyText: Love it 💟 . But avoid having a hooks file. Do for every hook its own file. But perhaps a hooks folder?
timeline.author: kmerz

replies.bodyText: Good point, having a look at comparable cases, I named the file useActiveBackend.js. I would create a hooks directory if we need to add more hooks.
replies.author: linuspahl

Bind auth plugins on all auth pages
Use a map binder and factories for provisioner actions

Set placeholder password for new users
Fix transportSecurity radio inputs and serverUrl input styling

Introduce EncryptedValue and related classes

This class contains an encrypted value and its salt. I can be used when
sensitive data must be stored in the database.

It comes with a custom JSON serializer and deserializer. They serialize
and deserialize the value in different ways depending on the context.
When storing/reading the value in/from MongoDB, the literal content
(encrypted value and salt) are read/written.
In all other contexts, the serialized JSON only contains an indicator if
the value is set or not. When parsing the JSON, only a "set_value" field
is allowed to set a new value.

The deserializer automatically creates an encrypted value and salt from
the given new plain text value.
Extract TrustManagerProvider into its own file so it can be reused

Fix user provisioning

We need to set an encrypted password value when creating a user.

Encrypt user password before passing it on to authentication services

This ensures that we don't expose it by accident (e.g. logging it)
All consumers need to decrypt it before they can use it.
